title: Improving Discovery of Open Civic Data
reviewer 2 notes:
TN: 
- paper describes how to develop an annotation for describing civic data, exemplarily for the ArcGIS Hub. 
- input data as existing concepts and vocabularies linked, but sometimes not available. Vocabularies are also available in the GitHub repository. 
- methods describe an evaluation (scripts missing), but results of this evaluation were not available at the time of publication. 
- it is therefore difficult to evaluate this paper. On the one hand, an implementation is described as a result, and on the other hand, an evaluation is described in the methods section, without corresponding results. However, as the implementation is described as an outcome, I judge it to be documented accordingly, but one may come to a different judgement here.

- parameter details are given by describing properties, formulas and a kind of detailed pseudo-code 
- results dataset can be found via zenodo, but not directly via the DOI in the paper, only via the linked research group website  
- python version used and networkx package version given, but no computing environment available. The research group's website states that source code will be released soon, but no link available

title: Terrain Prickliness: Theoretical Grounds for High Complexity Viewsheds
reviewer 2 notes: DN: new algorithm for viewshed computation, validated with experiements in real terrains; code on GitHub but no license or docs; other software described in text; data from Terrain layer in ArcGIS

title: User Preferences and the Shortest Path
reviewer 2 notes:
- Input data consists of personal daily routes, so sharing might be not possible anyway (I found no mention, though)
- No mention of code sharing in the paper

title: Map Matching for Semi-Restricted Trajectories
reviewer 2 notes:
- Data : They use OSM without any further information
- code & output : a Gh repo with SWHIDis provided but it doesn't overlap all the computational pipeline. It only does a tessallation but It doesn't match trajectories

title: Automated Georeferencing of Antarctic Species
reviewer 2 notes:
Input Data: data from gazetteers (New Zealand, SCAR, GeoNames) and species lists referenced, but no direct links provided.
Methods: machine learning classifiers documented, no code provided.
Results: documented with metrics, but no raw data shared.
Computational environment: Python and libraries mentioned (no versions), no hardware or OS details provided.

title: Do You Need Instructions Again? Predicting Wayfinding Instruction Demand
reviewer 2 notes: DN: navigation experiment with 45 participants; https://geoinfo.geo.tuwien.ac.at/resources/ says that there is "Published Code and Sample Dataset" at https://researchdata.tuwien.ac.at/doi/10.48436/yyhjf-bsh02, but the data seems to have been published later - the data DOI is not used in the paper yet! in any case, there is a Jupyter Notebook that does something with the test data, but no figures similar to the ones in the paper are plotted; the actually used DOI leads to a Zenodo record that seems incomplete (10.5281/zenodo.4298703) - very confusing! Nowhere seems to be the actual GPS data referenced, eye tracking data also seems to have been captured...;

title: Transitions in Dynamic Point Labeling
reviewer 2 notes:
- The input data (Twitter) and the source code for the prototype are NOT explicitly linked to the paper, but I managed to find them following the anonymized OSF link for the video demos. 
- Video demos showasing the functionality of the prototype linked
- HW specifications, OS, and libraries in Appendix.

title: Reducing False Discoveries in Statistically-Significant Regional-Colocation Mining: A Summary of Results
reviewer 2 notes:
- Data: Mobility data from a private compagnie. The dataest is described but not the filters used by the authors
- code & output: well described in the manuscript (no link provided)

title: Genetic Programming for Computationally Efficient Land Use Allocation Optimization
reviewer 2 notes:
Input Data: datasets (synthetic raster data and real-world vector data for Germany) are publicly available with links provided via Mendeley Data.
Methods: genetic programming for land use allocation is described, with code and workflows available online.
Results: results include visualizations, Pareto front comparisons, and accuracy metrics; raw data shared via repositories.
Computational Environment: mentions Python and Mendeley Data tools, but no details on hardware, OS, or runtime specifics. Use a benckmark to compare.

title: Visualizing Geophylogenies - Internal and External Labeling with Phylogenetic Tree Constraints
reviewer 2 notes:
Data: in GitHub
Methods: full code, libraries, Docker
Comp: OS, HW and requirements

title: Map Reproducibility in Geoscientific Publications: An Exploratory Study
reviewer 2 notes:
Data: List of papers available, but specific figures not identified, so it is not possible to reproduce the analysis
Method: Outline overall assessment, but specifics of repro attempts are not present. Cannot repeat.
Results: As above, overall summary. No specifics on individual reproductions.
Enviro: Hardware is presented, but what was used for each reproduction is not

title: Semi-Supervised Learning from Street-View Images and OpenStreetMap for Automatic Building Height Estimation
reviewer 2 notes:
Data: Mapillary; download scripts provided
Methods: GH repo & archive on softwareheritage.org

title: Towards a Multidimensional Interaction Framework for Promoting Public Engagement in Citizen Science Projects
reviewer 2 notes:
TN: 
Paper presents a framework for categorising citizen science interactions. The framework is then applied to the BioSenCS project as a case study.There is no computational analysis in this sense. The BioSenCS implementation is then presented as part of the paper. The code is available via GitHub and archived via SoftwareHeritage. A usability study was conducted, but the questionnaire, questions and raw results are not available. As the implementation is also presented in another paper and the focus here seems to be on the framework, I categorise this paper as conceptual paper.

title: Platial k-Anonymity: Improving Location Anonymity Through Temporal Popularity Signatures
reviewer 2 notes: DN: data collection and processing is described in detail, but created dataset likely due to commercial origin cannot be shared, also some steps missing ("manually reviewed and made minor adjustments"); processing described through text and formula;

title: Data-Spatial Layouts for Grid Maps
reviewer 2 notes:
- Input data can be accessed from original source. Paper does not specify which xls file from English census data. No data transformation steps for wikipedia table.
- Github link to source code for prototype. Incomplete instructions to run prototype. No license.
